Posts.Title: How Many Are We? DivineMrsM kt1966

Posts.Content: Mar 7, 2013 04:37PM Kazzie61 wrote: It sure is a tough road we're on.... I think we all have an idea in our heads of how long we have but actually hearing it makes it more real......the onc told me 6 to 12 months & I had in my head before that 6 months to maybe a couple of years if I was lucky. He did also say that about 10% will defy the odds so maybe that could be me....:) Jo, I'm jealous of old people too! Hell, I wanted to get old & retire with my hubby & pack up & travel the world... Now the reality is I won't even know my grand kids.......:( I haven't told my hubby (or anyone else for that matter) what the onc said! How do you do that?? It sure is a crap shoot...... Hugs to all. Karen x
Posts.Title: Prognosis Kazzie61 curveball

Posts.Content: Mar 2, 2013 02:48AM Kazzie61 wrote: It sure is an interesting conversation... I'm triple neg & the stats say the average lifespan after mets diagnosis is 9 months....I'm just past 9 months! I guess it all depends on the type of cancer, where it is & how we respond to treatment! I reckon the onc's must have a bit of an idea based on how quick it spreads, where it is & whether or not the treatment works..... I'm hoping the Xeloda works on me! The last 2 didn't & it spread to the liver whilst on them :( I'm like you MOX....don't hold out hope for years! Still think I wanna ask the question though..... Karen xx
Posts.Title: Prognosis Kazzie61 curveball

Posts.Content: Mar 1, 2013 09:40PM Kazzie61 wrote: Thanks girls.......I know I'm better off not knowing & I also know that the onc doesn't really know! Just something that's been running through my head lately... I'll just keep plodding along I think, thinking it could be months or it could be years....but hoping & praying for the latter.....:) Karen x
Posts.Title: Prognosis Kazzie61 curveball

Posts.Content: Oct 21, 2011 10:48PM Kazzie61 wrote: Hi ladies I rarely post but I do love reading all your posts, this one in particular - I especially love to see every ones pics:) I log in every day to check on the updates:) I had to post today & tell you all what a 'friend' said re my hair! I'm nearly 8 months PFC & was seriously starting to like my hair:) Anyway, I recently joined facebook & have been looking up some old friends. One in particular I was having a conversation with & as the time went on I told her I had breast cancer but was now cancer free. Her reply was 'I'm so glad that hair cut wasn't by choice LMAO'!!! Well, you can only imagine what that's done for my confidence! 2 steps forward 1 step back! LOL. Some people -arrrrrrrrr Karen x
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Mar 7, 2013 12:45AM Kazzie61 wrote: Well today I saw the onc & I asked the dreaded question! I won't say what he said as there may be some that would rather not hear the answer.... As I have triple negative it will be a true miracle if I'm around for years. I am pleased I asked the question as I feel I now know the reality of the situation......I do understand too that I could be one of those that way outlive the docs prognosis but not too hopeful of that.....just realistic.... Take care lovelies. Karen x
Posts.Title: Prognosis Kazzie61 curveball

Posts.Content: Mar 2, 2013 10:03PM Kazzie61 wrote: Hi Gail......didn't realize you we're on this site as well! I hear what everyone is saying & I do know that Dr Google is not a reliable source! It's just that I do keep wondering......in my mind I don't believe I'll still be here come Xmas, but that is based on what I've read..... Hubby & I wanna make holiday plans (I'm talking long overseas holiday, not short trips) & it's so hard coz I don't know where I'll be in 6 months.....even treatment wise it's hard. I know you're all in the same boat. I keep contradicting myself......I think I won't have too long one minute & the next I think there's no need to contact Palcare & make my arrangements yet!! Isn't it strange how before all this living a long time was probably another 30 odd years (based on being 50) & now we hope for 2 or 3 years...... I'm still not sure whether or not I'll ask the question (see the onc on Thursday) & I love reading everyone's opinions & thoughts on the subject. Karen x
Posts.Title: Prognosis Kazzie61 curveball

Posts.Content: Nov 9, 2011 03:08AM Kazzie61 wrote: Wow Dominika....you & your hair look amazing! I'm 8 months PFC & my hair is WAY behind yours...there's no way I can see me having as much hair as you have in another 5 months! My bangs are about 2 inches!!! Have you used any hair growth products i.e. Nioxin?? You sure will be a beautiful bride:)
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Jan 8, 2012 04:42AM Kazzie61 wrote: Racy...I chemically straightened my hair pre cancer & while I was very happy with it at first as time went on I felt like my hair had been ' cooked', it was very dry & not healthy looking! It's the same chemicals used for a perm. Personally I wouldn't do it again but everyone is different & maybe my hair just wasn't suited to the procedure.. Karen
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Kazzie61 wrote: Hi girls I'm just wondering how many of you have asked your onc what your prognosis is! I've always said I wouldn't ask as I really didnt want to know but am starting to consider asking the question......as scarey as the answer might be! Do our onc's really know the answer?? Would appreciate any comments or advice... Karen x Dx October 2010, Triple Negative, Stage 1, Grade 3, IBC. BMX with immediate DIEP May 2011. Now Stage 4. Posts.Content: Aug 6, 2013 10:04PM Kazzie61 wrote: I had my first scan after 3 rounds of Xeloda & I had an extra liver spot but the onc said to keep going a bit longer so another scan after 2 more rounds & slight shrinkage of one of the liver mets..... Another 3 rounds (I'm on 14/7) & the liver mets are barely visible....yay! Bone mets stayed stable. So I guess based on that it could take a few rounds to get results. Good luck. ((Hugs))) Karen x
Posts.Title: How long till xeloda kicks in blondie1 Kazzie61

Posts.Content: May 19, 2012 10:32PM Kazzie61 wrote: Hi Chrissy.....thanks for the info. I'm trying very hard to be patient & accept that I will find out the result on Tuesday but it's really hard not to worry....as I know you would understand!! I haven't told my husband...don't want him to have to worry particularly if it turns out to be just arthritis. On the other hand, if it turns out to be mets, to tell him with no warning would be very hard on him as well-:( Can't help but worry about everyone else LOL I live in Perth with my hubby, our gorgeous chocky Labrador & 2 grown children that have left home & since returned LOL Karen x
Posts.Title: If you are not Stage IV but have questions, you may post here chrissyb Olma61

Posts.Content: May 19, 2012 08:19PM Kazzie61 wrote: What a wonderful thread, I had no idea where to post my question until I came across this...... Yesterday I had a bone scan after a couple of months of lower back pain. Well, when it was over I asked the radiologist if they could see 'anything' & she hesitated & said 'yes we can, your doctor will discuss the results with you'!!!! My question is, can the radiologist tell the difference between cancer & arthritis at that stage or do they need to study the pics more thoroughly?? I've read that arthritis lights up just as cancer does, but really need to know if the trained eye would be able differentiate between the two right away!! I'm feeling very scared........ Karen x
Posts.Title: If you are not Stage IV but have questions, you may post here chrissyb Olma61

Posts.Content: Apr 16, 2013 04:18AM Kazzie61 wrote: Renae...so glad you had no progression & were avle to enjoy your birthday! And here's to many more to come!!! Angela...I do hope things are still going along ok for you. Always thinking of you & sending luv n (((hugs))) Karen...that sucks about the progression. I had progression on Gemzar also & have just finished 3rd cycle of Xeloda. I had my scans this morning, results on Thursday to see if it's working. I have a sneaking suspicion that all is not right with the brain scan due to something the radiologist said! Feeling pretty scared...... Our kids are so important to us.......anytime we can have with them is a blessing. Take care lovely ladies. Karen xoxox

Posts.Content: Sep 27, 2013 09:04PM - edited Sep 27, 2013 09:06PM by Kazzie61 Karen.....very interesting! My cancer sub-type is basal & it has gone to bones & liver....go figure!! I've been reading a bit about Metformin & intend asking my onc about it next visit. I've also read a lot about food, especially sugar, feeding cancer & keeping calories down particularly in Triple Neg!! I have been doing this ever since my secondary diagnosis & my onc is always saying I've done better than expected & my cancer hasn't 'behaved' like a normal Triple Neg.....who knows though. There are so many things written out there & a lot of them seem to be quite contradictive. I hope you can keep going with your 'doable' chemo & can keep a good quality of life. Big luv n hugs xxxx Have a good weekend girls. (((Hugs)) Karen xxx

Adnerb.....got everything crossed that your next scan is NED..... (((Hugs))) Karen xxx
Posts.Title: Triple Negative Stage IV Renae64 thrivingmama

Posts.Content: Dec 9, 2013 08:06PM Kazzie61 wrote: Carolben......yes, I did mean 2014!!! I'm scared it's the year my time will come...... My onc also believes my mets have been there since the beginning - October 2010 - as micromets. So I'm not sure if I've been stage 4 since October 2010 or May 2012 when I was officially diagnosed....sigh! Last March he said my prognosis was 6 to 12 months & then when the Xeloda worked he said that changed things. So who knows. I've been feeling quite anxious & 'scared' lately.....maybe I should get the bloody scan over & done with! Anyway, take care & hoping you get a good run out of Xeloda & very little side effects....:) (((Hugs))) Karen xxx
Posts.Title: Triple Negative Stage IV Renae64 thrivingmama

Posts.Content: Jul 21, 2014 02:08AM Kazzie61 wrote: Thank you ladies and your welcome for the update. I'm Nicole, mums youngest daughter with the grandson. Dad hasn't left her bedside since Friday night, sleeping in a reclining chair next to her. I spend my days at her bedside (and on her iPad) and dad ducks home for an hour to shower and returns. He won't leave until mum passes which we are expecting to happen within days. I've heard stories of people holding out for something or someone and as her doctor is so surprised she survived Friday night I thought maybe she's holding out to "say goodbye" to her grandson. I placed him against her side and wrapped her arm around him and although she is completely sedated and not moving she gently held onto Jaxon's leg and then let out a whimper like cry, I have no doubt she knew he was with her and I'm now praying that's all she needed to now let go. I would give anything to be by her side when it happens but I have a feeling she will save that special moment for just her and dad.
Posts.Title: Latest news on Kazzie61 chrissyb Annie62

Posts.Content: Jul 22, 2014 02:31AM Kazzie61 wrote: Thank you. Today just after midday mum opened her eyes for the first time since Saturday, both dad and I took her hand and she looked at us and took her last breath. I will treasure that moment forever but I'll have to wait until that image stops haunting my mind. I knew it was coming but I didn't think it ever would at the same time. Our lives have forever been changed with her loss. She knew I wanted to be there so I'm glad she waited for me.
Posts.Title: Latest news on Kazzie61 chrissyb Annie62

Posts.Content: Mar 10, 2013 06:13AM - edited Mar 10, 2013 06:14AM by Kazzie61 Another Stage 4 Triple Neg here..... Primary was diagnosed Oct 2010, multifocal, grade 3. Had 6 x TC chemo followed by BMX & reconstruction. May 2012 diagnosed with bone mets (had pain in spine & shoulder) then had radiation which helped with pain. November 2012 scans revealed 'major metastatic skeletal progression' so started chemo. I had 3 cycles of Paclitaxel/Gemzar & then scans showed slight progression of bone mets but it had spread to liver. So now on cycle 2 of Xeloda, scans after cycle 3 to see if it's working! Fingers crossed! Hugs to everyone. Karen x

Posts.Title: Triple Negative Stage IV Renae64 thrivingmama

Posts.Content: Jul 7, 2013 09:46PM Kazzie61 wrote: CSmommy....so sorry to hear of all your issues & fingers crossed you can get on the trial & that it gives good results....xxx Indiandeb....I have been on Xeloda since February this year. I have found it very doable & convenient, very few side effects. My first scan after 9 weeks (3 cycles) showed progression & then my next scan 6 weeks later showed stable in the bones & slight shrinkage in the liver. My next onc appointment is this Thursday so fingers crossed the bloods are all good....no scan this time! I rally hope to stay on this one for a long time! I haven't done Xempra but my onc has told it is a very harsh chemo....so hugs to all you girls on it.....(((hugs))) Take care. Karen x
Posts.Title: Triple Negative Stage IV Renae64 thrivingmama

Posts.Content: Aug 3, 2013 09:27PM Kazzie61 wrote: Debbiej.....I have found Xeloda very tolerable.. I've been very lucky with very few side effects but the best part is not having to go for infusions!!! As I've said it is working for me, first scan after 3 rounds showed progression in the liver & after another 2 rounds scans showed shrinkage & then the best part, after another 4 rounds the liver mets are barely visible....:) I'm on 2000mg in the am & 1500mg in the pm & on 14/7 schedule. It hasn't shrunk bone mets ( I have loads) but has kept them stable.....good enough for me. Obviously it doesn't work for everyone as OBXK has said (((hugs))) Karen. It's worth asking your onc about it, as we know all chemos are like a lottery.....no one really knows what's going to work. Good luck. (((Hugs))) Karen xxx
